header.rec_loc: A café in a tennis club, Solihull
header.topics: Weather, work, sport, education, family, living abroad, travel, music
header.activity: Acquaintances having a coffee in the tennis club café

body.u: it's a shame because last week I came in erm and did a couple of people here and we were outside cos it was beautiful weather
yeah unless you want to get soaking wet there's no point going out there
and freezing
yeah
it's a bit cold in there
even walking to my car is too much

I'm just learning how to drive and I'm getting quite glad that I am because I hate catching public transport in this weather it's so cold horrible so yeah tell me what you do here then and how long you've been working here
um I'm a tennis coach I've been working here for eight months now something like that
oh yeah?
I think just finished since last August so I just and all that sort of stuff and now coaching full time and doing quite well with it so
oh super
not doing too bad but it was just kind of it was something I fell into when I came back from France
uh huh
Cos I lived over there for two years
oh really?
and I knew the sports manager
uh huh
so I went up to he was at at that point so
is there a in ?
so I went over to there and then I just didn't do very well over there like there's just not as much money
okay
in that area so I was struggling a little bit and then he ah he moved down here and asked me to come with him cos they needed a bit of a performance programme for the kids so
ah oh so do you do mainly kids here or?
well I mainly do performance
aha what's that?
like kids trying to make it nationally or professionally or
oh right
cos I've been in that my whole life as well I mean I played on the pro tour
aha
just it's what I've been used to do I mean I coached my sister as well and she made top four under sixteens top ten under eighteens and
oh brilliant
now she's at university in America stud for free
to ah she got on a tennis scholarship?
scholarship yeah
brilliant whereabouts is she?
um Tampa Bay
Florida is that?
yeah
ah nice
because of the contacts I had over there she just sort of she asked me she said oh I can't I don't really want to play serious that much
uh huh

anymore and I'd like to go to uni and I said well you're not going in England I said if you can get it for free in America and she said ah oh ok and I went choose a place that you wanna go and I said I'll call my friends and they'll get you in over there and then she said Florida so
blimey who are your friends?
I know a lot of people
Yeah is that through the tennis circuit?
yeah I keep getting job offers over there in Dubai and Australia and
really? Why are you pretty pretty much based in England? Why not go somewhere else?
I dunno I've I've got I run a company and I've got three other businesses going at the moment so I
oh really? Blimey that's good what's that?
um my parents well we all we all run a pub in which is where I live
uh huh
trek here and back every single day
where is yeah?
it's ah do you know the M6 well?
no not that well
okay erm it's like in the middle from Birmingham and Wolverhampton
okay
it's up near and
uh huh
so it's in the middle of nowhere so it's a big drive here and back but yeah we run a pub and um my mum imports um jewellery like freshwater pearls and beads from China and sells them
uh huh oh wow uh huh
and my dad's a stand up comic and he still does it now
and um I do gigs as well I play guitar and I sing so I go all over the place doing that
ah wow
and a just a do as much as I can to survive I suppose
And do you live around here?
no
you live by?
I live in still in the pub like
ah okay
so but um it's not great but
no it's fine if you can you've obviously managed to get that balance between sport and ah enjoying yourself Go play tennis right now I'll have a pint
yeah but um it's alright
it's ah what what were you doing in France then?
I was coaching tennis
okay
at one of the biggest academies in the world
uh huh
it's like one of the top five in the world and I loved it over there but it's expensive and and the job wasn't the greatest
right
so at the end of the day all my friends left because the job wasn't the greatest and then I kinda was like I love it here but I'm not gonna stay here any longer it's everything kinda went sour
oh what a shame whereabouts is that in France?
um just next to Nice a little town called Sophia Antipolis
ah
it's like a big business complex and university type place
ah yeah one of those yeah like kind of it's got all the industrial parks and all the big businesses
yeah and just hotels and businesses and schools and colleges
aha
it's just a massive town like that but it was only about twenty twenty-five minutes away from Nice and twenty minutes from Cannes and
aha
just a bit further inland but it was brilliant out there and I adored it absolutely adored it
Were they were all your clients like the CEOs of all these big
yeah
japanese companies and stuff?
you'd like to think they're the CEOs whether or not their parents were doing a bit more dodgy business you have no idea
yeah yeah I know that's the kinda idea I get from all those little well big complexes like that in France
well the thing is who's got
because they just seem really sterile and everybody seems like they are behaving themselves too much so what's going on under the surface

but the thing is is who who can afford thirty grand just to send their kids to play tennis for a year? They do their school and they play tennis but it's thirty grand and then they got to play extras for tournaments and whatever else the kids are doing but they're all Russian and Serbian and
mhm
all sorts everyone from every country really
and what they send their kids to that tennis school for a year or are the parents living there as well?
no they just send them there like one a mo one the reason like I didn't like my job so much is because of what it entailed was I was a tennis coach coached like six to eight hours a day
mhm

I lived in the dormitories with the kids and had to look after them until they went to sleep I was a taxi driver there and back from the airport every single time they um needed a taxi driver to any of the tournaments they needed to go to
mhm
I I worked seven days a week
yeah
which was nonstop ten twelve hours a day
like a surro surrogate parent-cum-coach
yeah you know it was just you know I I don't think I had a day off in two years
really?
and the summer's intense over there because the amount of kids that they get to go over
yeah yeah yeah
it's um two months of just you know you're looking after between eighty and a hundred and twenty kids a week
you've got maybe maybe eight staff
mhm
at the place
frightening it's crazy isn't it?
just got hundreds and hundreds of kids just passing in and out and you got eight hour day in thirty-six degree heat
blimey
and then you got to get back and look after them then look after them on the weekends as well
and when do you get days off? Or time off?
you don't you don't
is that not against the law?
well not for the way that they hired me no
really? What was it just ah
yeah
hey would you like some paid work? Yes alright good was that a nod? Yes ok that's a contract there
they they they kinda dodgy in those places as well to be honest with you
mm
but erm
was it like a chain of tennis courts or
no if anything they've only just branched out they've branched out to Paris now as well
oh yeah?

so they got um they're starting to get a bit bigger and stuff but it's only because where they are at the moment it's so expensive that they can't really run what they're doing down there cos they run it from a Mercure hotel at the back of this hotel they've got like sixteen courts at the back of it it's so beautiful it's just ridiculous proper red clay courts with everything um they have to hire that they have to hire a building at the university so everyone can stay there and also use the golf course cos it's also a joint golf academy as well
mm is that where you were living? At the university? Nice nice in Nice

no it was beautiful I mean I loved it but just due to the fact that I was like nineteen twenty and I enjoyed going out and doing stuff that when you work for ten hours go out on a night and then try and wake up at six am the next morning and do it for the rest of the week especially when you go out two or three nights a week I mean at one point I had a band out there and we were doing three or four gigs a week so we'd be out till two AM and then up at six AM
mm yep yeah yeah yeah gosh yeah you can only do that when you're nineteen

Yea I remember I remember the one summer I went back home I had two two weeks holiday back at home after the summer and I went home and I honest to God slept for two weeks just didn't wake up cos I'd been living off three hours sleep for two months
mm nightmare you can't really function properly off that especially when you're looking after kids cos kids just suck so much energy out of you don't they they
and then just
take your eye off them

you you with all kinds of work there always ends up being the one kind of person who seems very incompetent at the job and you keep have to cover for them and I hated that over there so much cos I was working so hard over there there was one guy who was meant to be running like what we were doing and he was just never there but the problem was he was best friends with the boss
aha difficult situation
so I must have almost got him sacked about three times and the boss saved his bacon every time
oh no
so he didn't like me very much
And do you speak French then?
um I've gotten better at it yeah I mean the problem when I first got there was everyone wanted to learn English
yes I've heard that too

I was in an international academy and I was one of the only coaches who knew English the rest of them were very bad disjointed English so I kinda taught everybody English and for the first six months or something didn't learn any of it myself
aha aha yeah were you actually taug was it were any of your students French or were they mostly international?

some of them where the funniest part about it actually was most of my kids were like fore like Serbia Russian something like that so they knew English as well as well it was one of the things some of them were French and wanted to learn English but I remember they lobbed me with a job erm coaching the local school kids
mhm
so I had a bunch of six year olds who only spoke French so there you go okay I don't know what I'm going to be doing here
and they did that when I first got there so that was a difficult summer but it helped me out I mean having to learn the language that way is
yeah good motivator
yeah otherwise you've got a bunch of six year old kids just staring at you going I have no idea what you're talking about mate

I did that I was erm I had a class the th for for one of the first classes I had for when I moved to Spain and hadn't learnt Spanish before I went and learnt it there while I was living there and yeah I had a group of eh six and seven year olds I was in an English class but yeah once they realised that I didn't speak any Spanish they really tried it on and then they realised that I was going to give it to them in English r regardless of the fact that I didn't speak any Spanish they were going to get it from me if they behaved badly in an in a language that they didn't understand but uh
yeah mm yeah
you can express annoyance in international language
but the thing is body language body language is beautiful cos it works in any language
yep it's true it's true

but erm yeah no I mean just I fell into tennis just because and I've been doing it ever since I I mean I started late I started late for what any any coach anybody in this country will tell you I started at thirteen and they all told me I'd never make it anywhere
was that eh was that something your parents suggest you should do or was it something you wanted to do?
no It was it was quite strange I was a I was a cricket player when I was younger
yeah
but I got a strange in injury to my leg and like kinda big mental block playing cricket so my dad suggested that I move to tennis I wanted to play football
mhm
but we're Ozzies so he didn't really like football

so he kinda shepherded me round that and got me into tennis and you know I I I played from I was thirteen until I was fifteen just a couple of times a week and stuff we ended up going er travelling quite far distances to go to squads and learn from some of the coaches and then when I was like fifteen I I quit school and I did di like distance education
oh yeah?
learning from home cos I did that in Australia anyway
oh right

and erm I I did that from home so I trained eight hours a day got home and did my school work it just made it so much more simple because you can't get courts at night time you can't train at the times you want to after school and you're always tired after school
yep mm so who schooled you was it um your parents or you had a
myself
oh right

it was distance education from Australia again because umm when I was living in Australia I lived on a bus like a tour bus and ah my mum used to teach me but they they do they do it quite well from Australia the the books and stuff are well written
uh-uh so what were what were you living over there for?
in Australia?
yep
because of my parents are Australian my whole family is Australian
oh right
and I lived there till I was ten
did you?
mhm
where you born in Britain?
no
ah
I was born in Austral all my grandparents are English
aha
but all my other relatives are all Australian
aha so what's your nationality?
I've got both
aha ah
I've got dual citizenship
right
both passports
But you'd say you're a British you're a British national as much as an Australian national or?
I don't know I don't know I don't know if I've ever really felt at home in either place to be honest with you
mm yeah when you live between two places it's always
it's difficult because I grew up as an Ozzie I do I do feel Australian but I've lived a lot of my time here as well I lived a bit of time in France and I'd like to think I'm a bit French
Ooh la la So how how come you ended up moving back to Britain?
um my parents still lived here
ah
and when I when I quit my job in France I was I just needed to some stability again
mm but why did they move over?
why did they move over?
yep
we moved over here in 2000 cos of my dad's job because of comedy
ah
he wanted a different avenue to pursue
so he went he went down the moving countries route and we moved over here a few years went past and and we bought a pub up in in
mm mm
and that went really well and then we moved to
ah
worst decision of our lives
Why why did you go for was it a researched deci
because there was a tenni tennis centre there
ah okay

there was a tennis centre there and we were travelling from to there every single day and we figured hey we're living in a village we thought hey if we're living in a kind of town kind of area it can't do badly we'll just take the model that we've got here and put it in that pub down there died an absolute death oh my God it died
really? What's like?
dirty
really?
it's just it's not a great place but uh it's getting better slowly but I mean things have been going better since my mum's like the pub's not really even a pub anymore
what is it?
it's like a bead shop brassiere type thing
it's still got the beer and everything in it but because of my mum's beads and pearls she needs wall to wall in that now
aha oh wow
all the women who come there love it and the guys don't mind getting dragged along because they can have a pint
That sounds like a winning solution
so it's ah it's a good little good little one that one
does your mum actually make up the necklaces and bracelets as well or?
no we sell them wholesale
ah okay

we sell erm wholesale and people who either have small businesses or run shops of their own where they sell the made up stuff buy off us so but I mean she does fairs all over the country she's up in Scotland and God knows where selling the stuff all the time
sounds like fun
well it's not fun but it's something my a lot of my family's into
yeah?
my uncle in Australia and my cousin in America she had twenty-six stores at one point in America
blimey mhm and where are you family from in Australia cos my our family live out there as well?
kind of all over the place but the majority of them are in
oh yeah?
the majority of the family live in or off the coast on a couple of islands out there
aha nice
so we're from out that way but there's some one of my mum's brothers lives up in one in erm couple I think my dad's brother lives in
mhm mm my brother's in over the other side
it's nice
yeah lovely place and I never went to but
aw it's beautiful
but went to and the Barrier Reef and up to
Sydney bores me it's like any other city in the entire world and
really?
just doesn't just doesn't do it for me that's why I liked Nice it was strange it was a very different place it wasn't like a city it was old it was very old and they kept it that way
mm yep yep Nice is lovely
it wasn't like they'd tried to build new buildings and tried to cram up the place it was just
true but I guess it's got more history hasn't it?
yeah
it's cos the old quarter in Nice dates from quite a long time ago doesn't it?
yeah I used to spend most of my time down there and I loved Cannes as well
mm
the promenade down there was beautiful
mm
ah but no I'd with me I'd never know never know where I'm headed me
I'm twenty-one
are you?
yeah I've a lot of life ahead of me I hope
And what are your plans? Do you think?
no I have no I never have plans
no?
no but the one plan I had in my head is that I would like to buy a place in South France one day and like retire there
oh sounds like a good plan
but I would need so much money to do that I'm going to have to work very hard
I think you might You might have to coach tennis in your retirement
win the lottery no but like I mean still got the contacts over there I mean they're meant to be starting up a new Club Med have you ever heard of Club Med?
uh-uh
they're meant to be starting up a new Club Med tennis academy there
oh right
in 2013 or something and
isn't Club Med the kind of kind of a holiday you go on if you want to get drunk all the time?

no I don't know if no it's it it depends I think there might be some of those ones but the the one of my friends is working in um Sandpiper Bay in Florida at the moment and erm it's it's a real tennis academy
mm

it's intense but at a place which is like a five star hotel with um five star golf course and everything just it's amazing and I had friends out there coaching in France who were going to people's houses and coaching and taking a hundred euros an hour
mm yes wouldn't surprise me
if you can live your life like that you'd be alright
yes definitely if you can get the contacts of the people who can pay that much money
well you got to think realistically me being able to speak English it's all the ex-pat communities you want to be going to
mm
erm the people who who've moved over there in and have the money to spend on stuff like that
yep then again I don't know what the ex-pat community is like nowadays I know it's in Spain it's withered considerably after the
it's all in China these days
really?
oh all over there it's um it's a different place over there
mm
I went over there for like a week
mhm
that was strange
working or holidaying?
kind of yeah with my parents
oh to find the beads
yeah
but that was like six years ago was the last time I went to Australia haven't seen any of my family in six years
uh-uh oh
Don't get the chance it's uh too expensive the flights over there and
it is yeah my brother my brother always says oh are you coming to visit me and I'm like erm
I don't know it's not just that it's
have I got a spare couple of thousand in a month? No

it's not just it's not just that you know it's also the the fact that if you go to Australia with the jet lag and all that lot you don't want to be going there for a week or two weeks you want to be going for a month
definitely
or six weeks or something and then to get that time off work is almost impossible these days
yeah yeah yeah exactly yeah no the last time I went was I think it was two weeks and I spent the first week just feeling absolutely exhausted cause of the flight
it just knocks you out cos it's it's like ten hours in front you know is it ten hours in front? It's almost the opposite of the clock you've gotta change your entire body clock
yeah but even the just thirty hours in transit i e in you know travelling and
I'm alright with that cos I just sleep as soon as the plane turns its engine on gone
oh no no I was uh on I was travelling alone so I was had to sit next to other people who were travelling alone and I was sitting next to this huge fat smelly guy So for want of a better word he smelt
yeah
and uh he ate really loudly and he kinda just took up so much place I was couldn't really relax on the way over
I sat I solve all those problems I always get the window seat and I take an iPod with me stick the earphones goodnight to the world
You can
I normally put a jacket over my face or something so nobody can touch me

well a friend recommended that I take a piece of string and just sit there with a piece of string hang hanging out of one half and just sit there looking like I'm crazy and then no-one would want to sit next to me
and the the the especially like the short transit flights are it's a joke I fall asleep when the engine turns on and I wake up when the plane hits the tarmac
it doesn't matter if it's a two hour flight like I'll get on and go fall asleep and then boom oh well look I'm here quality
you're lucky very lucky hmm
I remember the amount of flights I've caught from here and France and back no luggage whatsoever just walked on with a tennis racket
being a tennis coach just walked on with a tennis racket sat down gone to sleep woken back up got off the plane and gone to work
That's a good commute So I guess you didn't get to come over and visit your family much when you were living in France did you?
I don't know whether it was a good thing or not
they go over to you? yeah did they go over to you at all?
yeah yeah they came and visit me quite a lot I mean it was a good little trip for them you know little few cheap hotels in the area and they could just come and stay with me for a bit and
I might be going to Nice at some point in the future I've got a a friend well I was friends with a family a Russian family when I was living in Barcelona I was teaching them English
yeah?

and erm they were from Uzbekistan And they'd moved away from Russia because they didn't he had a building construction industry uh company and he didn't want to be involved in all the corruption and scamming and that was going on what?
with the mafia
erm they moved to Barcelona to France erm Aix-En-Provence?
mm

and erm three years later he found his wife had been blown up in their car and she obviously died erm and then the next day he was put in prison for it when there was no evidence whatsoever that he'd done it he'd he'd got a witness saying that he was somewhere else and he's been battling this for the past seven years
was that French police or?
french police yeah they obviously just didn't you know they probably sniffed that it might be a mafia type crime and they just didn't want to touch it and

the French police are are quite strange the way they go about things because they're very laid back about everything you don't see police cars driving up and down the road you don't see people patrolling you won't see them walking through the streets the one thing I have seen I think I was in Lyon at the time and you don't see anybody and then this guy's walking down the street I saw a SWAT van pull up about twenty guys jump out of it and just bang grab this guy throw him in the back of the van and see you later and I'm like wow
yeah yeah definitely
it's either nothing or everything

yeah yeah yeah they are hard full on tactics to when I was um I used to work in Disneyland in Paris when I was at uni and uh one summer the Americans who worked there and lived in the same residence as me decided they wanted to have a a fourth of July party and so it was crazy I mean it was like a university residence and there was a rock band on one of the balconies and they were chucking fireworks into the crowd below and there was a lot of people around drinking and just having fun and exactly what the French people had were gonna do for their July the fourteenth holiday but somebody phoned the police and nobody came but about an hour later the CRS you know the riot squad they arrived and they just put themselves in position with their full riot gear and like everybody was just like oh what's going on carried on drinking and they just stayed there they didn't do anything they were just waiting for something to happen
yeah to happen

and one of the drunken American guys decided it would be a good idea to pull a moonie at them and so he just work went stand in front of them pulled his trousers down in front of them and they just absolutely leapt at him they they got the dogs on him the tear gas was going and from that tot that tiny action of
no they're just waiting for something give them an excuse and they'll go for it
yeah but they were brutal absolutely brutal it was crazy then again it was a stupid thing to do to go and moon the French CRS
you can't help people when they start to drink
But I guess in the place that you were the the Anatalie? What was it Sophia Anatalie
So Sophia Antipolis
that's it um I guess there were like private security police and
yeah
stuff like that cause like in some areas like that the police don't go there cause it's such an established community
no no I mean they have security guards everywhere for everything you know even at the university they've got their own personal security guards but thing was as well I was best friends with them
really?

I mean we had a swimming pool like exactly next to our complex and we used to go swimming in that three o'clock in the morning me and some guys and the security guards eh three o'clock in the morning let's go for a swim
mm
but um just it was it wasn't too bad it was not like they don't enforce anything but I think I only ever annoyed them once
mm what did you do?

I was playing like Playstation games at like two in the morning and I had my balcony window open and shouting and screaming as you do and they just come up and started going mental to me cos I was waking up the entire camp
oops
campus
and you were shouting at your?
yeah my friend
okay naughty boy that's no example to set to children
it was funny though yeah
so what's your work schedule like here?
I work six days a week
yeah?
I have a Tuesday off which is possibly the worst day in the world to have off cos you can do nothing on a Tuesday but no I work six days a week and I'll be in for like twelve hours every day
really? That's a lot of work
I'm not working that much I'm just here
no?
but the problem is cos I live so far away I can't go home I can't I can't really do anything I just have to sort of suck it up and try and get myself more work every time I'm down here
mm so how does it work do they feed you clients or what?
no I have to do it all myself
and how do you go about that?
talk to people be around as much as possible give out free lessons every once in a while to try and get people involved in it mm anything really I mean I do a lot of groups for this place
uh huh is that organised groups that they organise for you or?
yeah so that's all the money that they earn and I have to do that instead of like a rental fee
right
and I so I work all those groups and you can pick a few lessons out of groups and do other stuff so it's okay that way as well
mhm
but erm it's not bad it's not bad it's not brilliant but better than anything else I can get in this area
yes it's not fantastic for work round here is it?
I mean I'll never loo I'll never be out of a job as a tennis coach but it's it's not easy to get ahead in England as a tennis coach not very easy
no oh well you're not if you're not eh tied to England you could
no I mean
consider going other places
no I mean I'm just I'm I'm seeing what with my other businesses and stuff I'm seeing how that pans out really they kick off at me makes it worthwhile staying here if they don't I can be gone tomorrow
mm well then asleep on an airplane
and get oh yeah asleep on an airothan airplane with nothing packed but my tennis rackets and my guitar and I'll be alright
where would you like to end up apart from retired in the South of France? Where would you like to work?
oh Florida I could go there for a couple of years see my sister and work over there it'd be mental over there
that would be cool
and Dubai I wouldn't mind visiting there for a bit be a bit crazy with laws though
oh yeah
not to to sure I'm keen on their laws
You'd be like yeah I live in England in a pub they'd be like what? Cut his hands off

yeah but ah or in Australia I mean I've got all my family there I could go live with them and work over there but the thing is even there tax and everything has been hiked up over the past couple of years
really?
it's killing the country as well over there
mm and what's your sister doing in Florida then? What's she studying?
um American university is strange
yeah?
they study like everything
really?
yeah you don't major until like your last two years or something
oh really?

so she's there for four years and for the first two years you know you study everything you do maths English whate you've gotta choose like a bunch of classes to go to and you've gotta fill it up to fifteen credits so each class amounts to a different amount of credits so
mhm and what's she thinking of majoring in?
she wants to do fashion design
okay
Don't ask me why but she wants to do it but erm she can only stay in Tampa for two years cos it's a junior college
okay
because she fin she quit school after GCSEs and didn't do A-Levels
mhm aha

Cos of tennis she couldn't go straight into university they're very very very um tight on their laws on who can go to where and what like her tennis standard puts her in a division one school in America but she has to go to junior college for two years first and complete that before she can move onto the last two years at a division one school
oh right and will she do that in America do you think? Will she be allowed to?
yeah yeah
hey
she'll move she'll mo I mean she's got the highest they do it on grade point average GPA
oh yeah yep
she's got the highest GPA out of any athlete in her school
oh fantastic
so I think she got something ridiculous like a five point two which I think is the highest you can get she got straight As in everything basically
feel quite proud of her for that to be honest with you
what's she studying at the moment then? All the?
uh she's doing mathematics and psychology English history I think she's doing American history or something I don't know a bunch of other things I can't remember
and is she enjoying the the culture?
yeah she seems to be enjoying I think it's just it's a tough life as an athlete cos all you do is study and train
yeah

study train and compete if you enjoy the life you can get along with it I mean I was offered it so many times but I knew that when I when I quit tennis and I was like a model professional and I was playing I was I was doing eight hours a day didn't drink ate healthily never went out just kept myself good and then when I quit tennis I just went off the rails
mm yeah
I just went well from one from one like extreme to the other just absolutely went off took me a while to get back from there to be honest with you
really? how long and how bad did you get?
oh it was bad
you've not been deported that's a good sign
yeah it was it was it was bad especially when I was in France couple of bad relationships along the way and I was off
erm but uh no it was it was but uh I got I got myself back and uh I just knew I could never go to school I know I never enjoyed it
mm
